data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/Users/d12frosted/.atom/packages/org/lib...
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. `advanced-open-file`
2. navigate to `.org` file
3. open it
4. error

**Atom Version**: 1.0.11
**System**: Mac OS X 10.10.5
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/Users/d12frosted/.atom/packages/org/lib/org-input.coffee'

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/package.js:1036

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/Users/d12frosted/.atom/packages/org/lib/org-input.coffee'
  at Error (native)
  at Object.fs.openSync (fs.js:544:18)
  at Object.module.(anonymous function) [as openSync] (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:118:20)
  at Object.fs.readFileSync (fs.js:396:15)
  at Object.fs.readFileSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:369:29)
  at Object.exports._compileFile (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/season/node_modules/cson-parser/node_modules/coffee-script/lib/coffee-script/coffee-script.js:221:14)
```

data.title: Bare caret/dollar not found in search and replace
data.body: I'm trying to do a regex search and replace for start-of-line in order to prepend text to all of my lines in a file. However, a search for the caret character ('^') returns no results. This seems like a defect to me, I believe other editors such as Sublime and BBEdit/TextWrangler support this behavior. Note that a similar issue exists for the dollar sign character ('$').

data.title: Upload assets to pre & production releases from beta & stable branches
data.body:
Previously, CI would upload assets when building the `master` branch. Now, it uploads assets to a pre-release when building the `beta` branch, and to a normal release when building the `stable` branch.
- [x] Update build scripts to create and upload assets to pre and production releases from the `beta` and `stable` branches, respectively.
- [x] Create a `beta` branch off of this branch. Verify that after CI runs, a draft pre-release is created and populated with assets.
- [x] Create a `stable` branch off of this branch. Verify that after CI runs, the draft normal release is populated with assets.
- [x] Add `-beta` to Atom's version number on the `beta` branch.

data.title: :memo: Document `electron` label in Contributing guide
data.body:
This PR documents a new label, [`electron`](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+repo%3Aatom%2Fatom+is%3Aopen+label%3Aelectron), which should make it clearer when Atom bugs / enhancement requests require changes in Electron to happen. :zap: 

/cc @atom/issue-triage

data.title: Faster Style Recalculations
data.body:
- [x] Reopen https://github.com/atom/git-diff/issues/71 after :ship:ping this.
- [x] Merge https://github.com/atom/git-diff/pull/73.
- [x] Merge https://github.com/atom/bookmarks/pull/39.

In this PR I have removed inline styles from lines and got rid of a couple of classes that were not used for styling. To do that, I sorted line and line numbers by their screen row.

Before (full reflow):

![before-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/9761178/653b5f3a-56fb-11e5-9236-66e6a5368b67.png)
![before-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/9761179/65403258-56fb-11e5-854a-c05c9f5031d6.png)

After (full reflow):

![after-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/9761186/6e2d7ff6-56fb-11e5-8eb7-beadac1e1862.png)
![after-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/9761184/6dcf02be-56fb-11e5-9250-3cf452c1de9f.png)

:racehorse: :racehorse: :racehorse: 

Please note that this regresses https://github.com/atom/git-diff/issues/71 because we cannot set inline z-indexes anymore on line nodes. @simurai: in the meantime, I feel like I'd be down to have the git deletion marker styled like:

![deletion-marker](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/9516321/ed2090d2-4ce2-11e5-8664-08f3f6a019ca.png)

Or, alternatively, to avoid assigning an opaque background to the cursor line number.

Thoughts? :thought_balloon: 

/cc: @nathansobo @atom/feedback

data.title: Atom doesn't use gtk3 file dialog on Gnome 3
data.body:
Fedora 22 Workstation. Atom 1.0.11.

When opening or "saving as" a file, Atom uses gtk2 file dialog instead of using modern, gtk3 file dialog.

How currently Atom file open dialog looks:
![atom-gtk2-file-open-dialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4953862/9760654/5b00662c-56f7-11e5-9357-e8939e5bf4f6.png)

How it could look if Atom was using gtk3 file open dialog window:
![atom-gtk3-file-open-dialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4953862/9760663/6db8ba4e-56f7-11e5-9cb9-05c51f5a01f5.png)

```
3.16.0-48-generic #64~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Thu Aug 20 23:03:49 UTC 2015 i686 i686 i686 GNU/Linux
```

Any idea how to install atom?

Cheers!
Jerry

data.title: File finder shows 'Project is empty' when parent repository .gitignore targets child repository.
data.body:
I have a parent repository within which I have child repositories. This is an example which shows a similar layout:

```
C:.
├───.git
├───.gitignore
├───.gitattributes
├───README.md
├───child-1
│   ├───.git
│   ├───.gitignore
│   ├───.gitattributes
│   └───README.md
└───child-2
    ├───.git
    ├───.gitignore
    ├───.gitattributes
    └───README.md
```

I don't want to track child repository files from parent repository so I have configured the parent repository .gitignore in order to ignore every directory. This is how the .gitignore shows:

```
*/
```

Changes in child repositories are tracked as ususal and, when I open a child repository in atom, changes can be seen in atom tree view and status bar. I can also look for changes in git status finder but, when I toggle file finder, it shows 'Project is empty'. If I remove .gitignore from parent repository file finder shows project files as usual.
# Steps to reproduce

These are the steps to reproduce in Windows with GitHub for Desktop Shell (PowerShell):

``` PowerShell
git init parent
cd parent
sc .gitignore '*/' 
ni .gitattributes,README.md
git add -A
git commit -m ':boom:'
git init child-1
cd child-1
ni .gitattributes,.gitignore,README.md
git add -A
git commit -m ':boom:'
atom .
```

And then toggle file finder (Ctrl+P).

data.title: Disabled package is enabled when updated
data.body:
Had the linter-clang package as disabled when prompted that a new update was out. When finalized, package was suddenly enabled.

Caused an issue as I already had linter-gcc installed which utilizes the same key commands, thus colliding.

data.title: Code folding (and indentation) is broken when using java
data.body:
Code folding using Java is broken for me.
I am using version 1.0.11.
On the screenshots you can see, that instead of folding the method and only displaying the method-head it only hides the curly bracket below the line of code inside the method. This is usually not what you want when using code folding.

unfolded:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5699586/9755953/96fcfe36-56d6-11e5-87b7-8e14acb57b88.png)
folded:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5699586/9755979/ca4bd79e-56d6-11e5-8c9a-018318892392.png)

Indentation also seems to be weird, but I can not confirm that now.

data.title: Trim whitespace not working on Jade files
data.body:
How to reproduce?
Make a `file.jade` and enter and tab a bunch. Then save.

This is especially annoying in Jade because it can result in extra whitespace lines in the output. I understand if there is a reason for not doing this for indentation languages but Is there anyway to re-enable it?

data.title: Atom forgets the syntax coloring in Makefiles...
data.body:
In a makefile, it's perfectly okay to have rules like this:

``` makefile
all:
    make TEMP

clean:
    rm -f TEMP

```

But, Atom was able to interpret only the first rule, as you can see here. The following ones are simply displayed as text.

![shot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6691262/9754610/9cf1209e-56e8-11e5-819a-4a348bdbf1e2.png)

**OS**: Ubuntu 14.04 (x64)
**Atom version:** 1.0.0

data.title: Add --no-auto-update while run `scripts/build` to disable autoupdate
data.body:
Add `--no-auto-update` to script/build as an option to disable Atom autoupdate.

This PR create a new grunt task that set `_enableAutoUpdate` to Atom's package.json while building. And in AutoupdateManager, it loads package.json and check if `_enableAutoupdate` is set.

I verified that `script/build --no-auto-update` will set `"_enableAutoUpdate" : false` in Atom's package.json whereas `script/build` will  set `"_enableAutoUpdate" : true`. 

However, it seems that the build generated by `script/build` won't trigger autoupdate even if I made the the version to be `1.0.9` instead of `1.0.9-somehash`.

Any thought on how to verify the autoupdate feature using `script/build`?

cc @bolinfest  @maxbrunsfeld  @kevinsawicki

data.title: Autoupdate doesn't work well if Atom is owned by root on Mac.
data.body:
I have Atom.app installed in /Application/Atom.app and it's owned by root but readable and executable by all users.

When I first launched, I got a request to install a helper application to keep it up to date. 
I did so, and it told me to quit and relaunch.  
The next relaunch asked me the same question, and caused Atom to crash and close.  I reopened it again and it had finally updated, but now I see two entries in the "Open with..." menu:

![screen shot 2015-09-02 at 11 27 57 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/837180/9749879/fdad3b50-5645-11e5-99f9-3095f618465a.png)

data.title: atom shows nonexistent blank lines at the ends of files
data.body: If I have a file with 1 line as shown by wc and vim, atom will display two lines complete with line numbers. All files end in a newline character, but that does not mean there is an actual line there (newlines mark the end of lines, not the beginning). This is annoying and results in weird complaints from Windows users who don't understand the trailing newline convention.

data.title: Suggestion, if I'm in wrong place let me know I'm firstimer to GitHub
data.body:
So Hi,
I think it may already be asked/suggested, but is there a possibility of adding option to "open with Atom" to the windows thingy that pops when you right click a file :)

Sorry for my English I'm ESL :D 
I'm sorry if I' bothering you with something and just wasting your time but I'd love this feature added ;]
-Jackob

data.title: SCSS with brackets causing
data.body:
I've noticed that using brackets inside a class/id will break the theming of code after.

![screenclip](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1281284/9744152/14a6688a-5638-11e5-931a-55ef9b556a4f.png)

I am on Atom 1.0.11 as of this posting. I switched back to the One Dark UI and theme, but that did not fix the issue. Removing all plugins did not fix it either.

I am at a loss as to what to do next. Any idea why this is happening?

Thanks.

data.title: Need a better way to switch between UI themes.
data.body: It'd be nice to have a drop down just for this that made changes. I think this would be easy and useful.

data.title: Correctly terminate scopes that end at the beginning of a line
data.body:
Closes #8703
Fixes #8701

Major props to @Ingramz for discovering this obscure bug in `TokenIterator`. This PR adds a test and adjusts the implementation slightly, while incorporating his original commits. Thanks so much for your contribution :metal:.

data.title: The "package management" views are placed in the "preferences" menu
data.body:
Another naming / usability issue, sorry ...

There is a "packages" menu item in atom. What it really contains are the "installed packages" and not things related to "packages".

To reach the "package management" functions however, I have to navigate through "Edit > Preferences" and select "Packages" there.

IMO it would be more intuitive to add a separator at the beginning or the end of the "packages" menu, put "Manage Packages ..." or "Manage Installed Packages ..." and "Install New Packages ..." there, and remove these functions from the "Preferences" menu.

Admittedly, yes, some packages offer customization, and it indeed comfortable to install a package and then customize by simply clicking on the gear icon that is displayed next to the "uninstall" button. But the same button could as well link to a dedicated, plugin-specific section in the "real" settings page.

data.title: The "settings" view is named "preferences" in the menu
data.body: Different names for the same thing aren't intuitive. Could one term be chosen and then be used throughout the user interface?

data.title: "Installed On" date is wrong in Windows 7 "Programs and Features"
data.body:
I was uninstalling unneeded programs through the Windows 7 "Uninstall or change a program" menu, and I noticed that Atom is said to have been installed on 12/3/2015. I am in the USA, so this date would be December 3, 2015, which hasn't happened yet--today is September 8, 2015 (9/8/2015). Atom is listed as version 1.0.11.

I don't really know how to give any more info except that it is obviously wrong. As far as I know, the system time was never changed, and no other applications seem to share this problem. Also, the editor was probably installed about a month ago, so it is not likely that just the month and day were flipped.
